text: thanks everyone!
is there a limit to the size of an extra sent via broadcast intent?
my broadcast receiver isn’t receiving the call from the service when the data passed as an extra is too long
<@U04VA47NB>: yes, there is a limit on data which could be sent between processes (`Bundle`)
<@U04VA47NB>: you can save data into the file, db, etc and send identifier in the intent and read it from the receiver
hmm ok thanks
i read somewhere it's about 1MB
yep, this limit can be different between OS versions
great. thanks guys
how much data are you putting into a bundle?
lol. I wasn’t going to ask
yes never exceed 1MB. The less the better send a URI instead
I’m putting one string
but it’s really long
I’m calling the reddit api: `<http://www.reddit.com/r/funny/new.json?limit=100>`
so it returns 100 posts
but with 30, it works
doesn't seem to be _that_ much
you wouldn’t think so, but my receiver isn’t being called
afaik we send rather large XML docs over intents
and nothing in the logs?
no nothing
I make sure that I actually get a result by logging the data in the intent service, and then nothing happens after that in the logs
<@U04VA47NB>: intents should fail on broadcasting for exceeding the limit
localbroadcasts may be an exception
the limit being 1MB?
may be lower on some platforms
but not _that_ low?
the total size of the extras being 1MB but you can’t guarantee you are in the limit in certain cases
also, does it need to  be a string, or can you pass the serialized/parceled model objects along?
String is parceled internally
I’ve never understood the serialization/parcelable concept
nvm then :smile:
one second
there is that article about parcelable vs serializable and bundle max
<http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/ext/com.google.android/android/5.1.1_r1/android/os/BaseBundle.java#BaseBundle.writeToParcelInner%28android.os.Parcel%2Cint%29>

attachments.text: android.os.BaseBundle - A mapping from String values to various types
attachments.fallback: android.os.BaseBundle - A mapping from String values to various types

text: so there you can see all entries end up being written to a parcel which is what is really sent when data is moved around
so to answer the underlying issue we are talking about sending bytes between two things and parcelable exists and is used in intents for one purpose, to support IPC
a lot of the time they are used in non IPC use cases which is fine but the hard internal limit is intentional so you can’t cause excessive memory use in the system or receiving application(s)
in the case of parceable and serialization the concept is moving complex data into simple data that can be restored later on if ever
IPC is important in distinguishing the two though as serialization implies permanent structure and parceable makes no guarantees it will work outside of the runtime
<@U04VA47NB>: if you have any issues with the reddit api let me know, there are some pain points with certain endpoints i’ve experienced :confused:
<@U055GGAHS>: thanks for that. what do you mean by permanent structure?

and to back up my previous claim of strings are actually parceled internally.. <http://grepcode.com/file/repository.grepcode.com/java/ext/com.google.android/android/5.1.1_r1/android/os/Parcel.java#Parcel.writeValue%28java.lang.Object%29>

attachments.text: android.os.Parcel - Container for a message (data and object references) that can be sent through an IBinder
attachments.fallback: android.os.Parcel - Container for a message (data and object references) that can be sent through an IBinder

text: <@U0546QERR>: thanks, this is more of a practice app, but if I get stuck again, i’ll let you know :simple_smile:

if you have POJO object and you needed to serialize it to disk for instance, the serialization/externalization implementations of java guarantee that any JVM can read back that object (that I know of)

Parceable makes no guarantees outside of the runtime which is important when considering things like versions of an object or compatibility between applications, you should assume failure vs serialization where you should probably assume success (granted versioning causes all kinds of issues and you will generally find that using java serialization is a pita and should just avoid it entirely)
tldr don’t try to write a parceable to disk or send it between devices, use something intended for the job instead
so parcelable would work fine/better than serialization for sending objects during runtime
but if I rely on a parcelable object to be persisted between runtimes, there’s no guarantee that it’ll work
yes parceable is much faster than the java serialization/externalization as it only bothers to understand basic types vs understanding everything
yes I would say your assertion/summary is correct
<http://developer.android.com/reference/android/os/Parcel.html>
that warning there is what I was trying to explain
hopefully that clears up serialization/parcelable for you

Generally you should not be sending payload through intents, send the meta data. In this case you could just cache the info in some data class that your UI relies on. If you did this then your intent would only need to tell the UI the data has updated/changed/ etc
